data.title: Van Williamson
data.meta_description: Bio. Van Williamson, a jazz group from Stevensville, MD
data.text:
Guitarist Van Williamson was for many years a producer on NPR’s Morning Edition, and the director of the show before retiring to devote more time to music. As an independent radio producer, he created the long-running music-variety program Radio from Downtown at the Avalon Theatre in Easton, MD.

He’s a graduate of San Francisco State University and spent many years in the Bay Area playing with local theater groups and in jazz and bluegrass bands, and was a founding member of The Electric Guitar Quartet, an ensemble specializing in the performance of classical string quartet music on electric guitars.

Since relocating to the East Coast, he has played in a wide variety of local venues as a soloist or in a duo, trio, etc format, including the Rehoboth Jazz Festival (since 1990), the Rehoboth Art League (since 2000), NPR, Salisbury University, Chesapeake College, the Queen Anne's County Arts Council, and many clubs and restaurants on the Delmarva Peninsula, Annapolis, Baltimore, and DC.

He has also performed with the Delmarva Big Band, the Queen Anne’s Chorale, the Bay Jazz Project, the Joe Baione Trio, the No No Nonette and David Schulman’s Quiet Life Motel and other small groups around the region. Since 2018 he has been performing with Los DayTrippers, a sextet specializing in Beatles music with Latin rhythms. in 2021 he wrote music for a documentary film about the Chesapeake Bay watershed, Water's Way, by Tom Horton, Dave Harp, and Sandy Cannon-Brown. The film premiered at the Chesapeake Film Festival in October.

He has studied with guitarist Steve Herberman and with Jeff Antoniuk's Jazz Band Master Class.
